questions.question: How ……………………… do you speak English?
questions.description: Good is an adjective well is an adverb. The modify the verb speak, we need the adverb well.

questions.question: She looked rather …………………………
questions.description: Look is a copular verb. We use adjectives, not adverbs to modify copular verbs.

questions.question: I can’t tell you ………………………. pleased I am about the result.
questions.description: How much is not used before adjectives and adverbs. Instead we use how.

questions.question: I drove …………………….. fast as I could.
questions.description: Much is not used with as before adjectives and adverbs.

questions.question: I am ………………………. worried about her health.
questions.description: Very is used without much before adjectives and adverbs.

questions.question: You are ………………………… generous.
questions.description: Too is used without much before adjectives and adverbs.

questions.question: This essay is …………………………… more interesting than the other essay.
questions.description: Much or a lot is possible here. Quite cannot be used before comparative adjectives.

questions.question: The movie was …………………………… interesting.
questions.description: Quite is the correct answer here. It can be used before adjectives in the positive degree.

questions.question: Today is ………………………. hotter than yesterday.
questions.description: Very cannot be used before comparative adjectives.

questions.question: She is ………………………. a poet than a playwright.
questions.description: Less of can be used to modify a description.

questions.question: It is going to be ………………………………
questions.description: Indeed is not normally used without very after adjective / adverb.

questions.question: I have ............................................... interest in politics.
questions.description: Less and least are the comparative and superlative forms of little. When there is no idea of comparison we use the positive adjective.
